I personally think that even a question like "How does the International Court enforce it's decisions?" would be off-topic for this site. I also don't see it as "restricting" the site's scope... I see it as **defining** the scope. And I think that's something we have to do *now*.

I think the former is less of a problem than the latter at the moment. We can try and see if we end up with a valuable content, separate from wikipedia, with the more restrictive parameters, but if we leave it open we really can't cut back the site if it explodes into an everything mess.

If you look at how questions tend to be closed on Stack Exchange, there is almost always a comment explaining the close reason (often left by someone who doesn't have enough rep to close), so that would be a good enough place to leave the "forwarding URL." In other words, don't close a question because it's a dupe of info available elsewhere on the internet... close a question because the *Wikipedia* article on the topic is really a very complete answer and you wouldn't *have* to search to find it.

No, everything on Wikipedia is **not** Creative Commons, and you are not allowed to just use it. The images hosted there have a wide variety of licensing restrictions. They range from public domain through Creative Commons and GNU licenses to copyrighted images with no licence, just a claim of "fair use" of somebody else's image. Use of Creative Commons or similar usually requires "attribution" - that is, explicitly stating the source of the image, and perhaps further requirements.

@mgkrebbs: Both SO and Wikipedia operate under a creative commons license. If the licenses are compatible, then we can legal use images from Wikipedia. We don't have to create every image in the site, we just have to make sure every image is either our creation, or licensed appropriately.
